results.title: Smokes and Lollies
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Penny Chapman, 1:1 Films and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: First film in a longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, aged thirteen and fourteen. They talk about their attitudes to sex and boys, pregnancy, abortion, marriage, school, parenthood and their careers. Their hopes and ambitions pose special questions for adults and young people alike. Edited by David Pulbrook; sound by Rod Pascoe and photographed by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Telephones: using and abusing
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, E Brereton and Post Office Film Unit
results.brief_description: A dramatised account promoting speedy and efficient use of the telephone. Guides us in the correct methods of dialling, answering and speaking on the telephone. With animation explains the complex sequence of operations within an automatic exchange when a call is made.

results.title: Click go the shears
results.creator_credit: Jerome Levy, Keith Gow and Link Films
results.brief_description: A highly stylised humorous treatment of the famous Australian ballad, using a minimum of animation. Sung by Cedric McLaughlin and the Link Singers.

results.title: 14's good, 18's better
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Hilary Linstead, Timothy Read, Big Picture, Film Australia and M and L
results.brief_description: A longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, now 18, intercut with footage from “Smokes and lollies”, shot when they were 14. Their previous expectations have been altered by the experiences of marriage, parenthood, employment, low incomes and insecurity. However, they remain optimistic, with their humour intact. (Awards: Winner, Best Australian Educational Short Film, Australian Teachers of Media (ATOM) Awards, 1982)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Hilary Linstead, Timothy Read, Big Picture, Film Australia and M and L

results.title: More smokes less lollies
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Hilary Linstead, Timothy Read, Big Picture, Film Australia and M and L
results.brief_description: Edited version of “Fourteen’s Good, Eighteen’s Better” and sequel to “Smokes and Lollies”, this is the second part in a planned four part longitudinal study of three young women in Adelaide who reflect on their past and futures as 18 year-olds: one single, another married and expeecting her first baby and the third divorced with two children. Each discusses her teenage years and attitude to marriage, sex and abortion. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Hilary Linstead, Timothy Read, Big Picture, Film Australia and M and L

results.title: Sweet are the fruits
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the growing and harvesting of pears, apricots and peaches in the Ardmona District of Northern Victoria. Shows the huge cannery in operation at Mooroopna - grading, peeling, coring, cutting, filling cans, adding syrup and sterilizing, labelling, packaging and finally despatching cartons. Gives a picture of a worker’s typical day and life in the caravan park. Features Joan Harris and Frederick Parslow.
results.description: Tells the story of the growing and harvesting of pears, apricots and peaches in the Ardmona District of Northern Victoria. Shows the huge cannery in operation at Mooroopna - grading, peeling, coring, cutting, filling cans, adding syrup and sterilizing, labelling, packaging and finally despatching cartons. results.title: Now you're talking
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of Australian Cinema Series”.
The 30s saw the introduction of the “talkies” and a new era of filmmaking began. This was to decline with World War II. Excerpts from many of the films made during this decade are seen in this video. Please note that the commentary by Leo McKern has been recorded on another channel and may not be heard over the original sound recording. Includes b&w sequences.

results.title: Let's look at railways
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This film outlines the importance of railways to Australia. It shows the Australian railway system as an important means of transport for primary products, mail and people; traces the history of rail transport from the time of the Industrial Revolution; the effect of introducing railway transport in Australia; the break of gauge problems; the development of powerful locomotives in various states to cope with modern heavy haulages; the future of railways in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Spotlights: Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama. Her films often feature female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors and also mentions My Brilliant Career (1979), which features in the New Wave section of Moving Australia.

constellations_primary.name: Brilliant careers (Gillian Armstrong)
constellations_primary.description: Gillian Armstrong's feature film debut not only helped launch her own acclaimed career, but those of the actors as well.

results.description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama, Gillian Armstrong’s work often features female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors as well as her groundbreaking debut My Brilliant Career (1979).
description_for_label: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama, Gillian Armstrong’s work often features female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors as well as her groundbreaking debut My Brilliant Career (1979).
